hero.title: Health Savings Accounts and Flexible Spending Accounts
hero.subtitle: Tax-advantaged accounts that help you save for medical expenses

content.introduction: Health Savings Accounts (HSAs) and Flexible Spending Accounts (FSAs) are powerful tools that allow you to set aside pre-tax dollars for medical expenses. Understanding the differences between these accounts and how to maximize their benefits can save you thousands of dollars over your lifetime.
keyPoints: HSAs offer triple tax advantages: tax-deductible contributions, tax-free growth, and tax-free withdrawals for qualified expenses
FSAs are 'use it or lose it' accounts with annual contribution limits
HSAs require enrollment in a high-deductible health plan (HDHP)
Both accounts can cover a wide range of medical expenses beyond just doctor visits
HSA funds roll over year to year and can be invested for long-term growth

sections.title: Understanding HSAs
sections.content: A Health Savings Account is a tax-advantaged savings account available to individuals enrolled in a high-deductible health plan (HDHP). For 2024, an HDHP is defined as a plan with a minimum deductible of $1,600 for individuals or $3,200 for families. HSAs offer unique triple tax benefits: contributions are tax-deductible, the money grows tax-free, and withdrawals for qualified medical expenses are tax-free. Unlike FSAs, HSA funds roll over year to year, making them excellent long-term savings vehicles. You own your HSA even if you change jobs or health plans.

sections.title: Understanding FSAs
sections.content: Flexible Spending Accounts are employer-sponsored benefit accounts that allow you to set aside pre-tax dollars for eligible healthcare expenses. The key difference from HSAs is that FSAs typically operate on a 'use it or lose it' basis—funds must be used within the plan year or you forfeit them. Some employers offer a grace period (up to 2.5 months) or allow you to carry over up to $610 into the next year. FSAs don't require enrollment in an HDHP and can be used alongside any health insurance plan. The 2024 contribution limit is $3,050.

sections.title: Contribution Limits and Eligibility
sections.content: For 2024, HSA contribution limits are $4,150 for individuals and $8,300 for families, with an additional $1,000 catch-up contribution allowed for those 55 and older. To be eligible for an HSA, you must be enrolled in an HDHP, not be claimed as a dependent on someone else's tax return, and not be enrolled in Medicare. FSA contribution limits are $3,050 for healthcare FSAs. You cannot contribute to both an HSA and a healthcare FSA in the same year, though you can have a limited-purpose FSA (for dental and vision only) alongside an HSA.

sections.title: Qualified Medical Expenses
sections.content: Both HSAs and FSAs can be used for a wide range of qualified medical expenses as defined by the IRS. This includes doctor visits, prescription medications, dental care, vision care, mental health services, and medical equipment. Over-the-counter medications and menstrual products are also eligible. HSAs can even be used for COBRA premiums and long-term care insurance premiums. Keep all receipts for your records—with an HSA, you can reimburse yourself years later for expenses you paid out of pocket, as long as they occurred after you opened the account.

sections.title: Investment Strategies
sections.content: One of HSA's most powerful features is the ability to invest your balance once it reaches a certain threshold (typically $1,000-$2,000). This transforms your HSA from a simple savings account into a retirement planning tool. Many financial experts recommend paying medical expenses out of pocket if you can afford it, allowing your HSA to grow tax-free for decades. After age 65, you can withdraw HSA funds for any purpose without penalty (though non-medical withdrawals are taxed as ordinary income), making it function like a traditional IRA with the added benefit of tax-free medical withdrawals.

sections.title: Common Mistakes to Avoid
sections.content: Don't over-contribute to an FSA—carefully estimate your annual medical expenses to avoid forfeiting funds. With HSAs, avoid withdrawing funds for non-medical expenses before age 65, as you'll face a 20% penalty plus income tax. Keep detailed records of all medical expenses and HSA withdrawals for tax purposes. Don't assume you can't have an HSA if you're on Medicare—you can't contribute once enrolled, but you can still use existing funds. Finally, don't leave HSA funds sitting in cash if you don't need them immediately—invest for long-term growth.

callouts.title: Pro Strategy
callouts.content: Treat your HSA as a retirement account by maxing out contributions, investing the balance, and paying medical expenses out of pocket. Save all medical receipts—you can reimburse yourself decades later, tax-free, creating a powerful tax-free withdrawal strategy in retirement.

callouts.title: FSA Deadline Alert
callouts.content: FSA funds typically expire at year-end. Check your plan's specific rules about grace periods or carryover amounts. Set a reminder in November to use remaining funds on eligible expenses like prescription sunglasses, dental work, or stocking up on first aid supplies.

callouts.title: Real-World Scenario
callouts.content: Sarah, 30, contributes $4,150 annually to her HSA and invests it in a low-cost index fund. She pays medical expenses out of pocket and saves receipts. By age 65, assuming 7% annual returns, her HSA could grow to over $500,000—all available tax-free for medical expenses or as taxable income for any purpose.

practicalSteps.title: Evaluate Your Health Plan
practicalSteps.description: Determine if you have an HDHP that qualifies you for an HSA, or if your employer offers an FSA. Compare the benefits of each based on your expected medical expenses.

practicalSteps.title: Calculate Your Contribution
practicalSteps.description: For FSAs, carefully estimate annual medical expenses. For HSAs, consider contributing the maximum if possible, especially if you can afford to pay medical expenses out of pocket.

practicalSteps.title: Set Up Automatic Contributions
practicalSteps.description: Arrange payroll deductions or automatic transfers to fund your account consistently throughout the year. This makes it easier to reach contribution limits.

practicalSteps.title: Organize Your Documentation
practicalSteps.description: Create a system for saving medical receipts and tracking expenses. Use apps or spreadsheets to categorize expenses and match them to account withdrawals.

practicalSteps.title: Invest Your HSA Balance
practicalSteps.description: Once your HSA reaches the minimum threshold, invest in low-cost index funds appropriate for your time horizon. Keep enough in cash for near-term medical needs.

practicalSteps.title: Review and Adjust Annually
practicalSteps.description: Each year during open enrollment, reassess your health plan choice and contribution amounts based on your medical needs and financial situation.

quiz.question: What is the main advantage of an HSA over an FSA?
options: HSA funds roll over year to year and can be invested
HSAs don't require a high-deductible health plan
HSAs can be used for any expense
quiz.explanation: The primary advantage of an HSA is that funds roll over indefinitely and can be invested for long-term growth, unlike FSAs which typically operate on a 'use it or lose it' basis. HSAs also offer triple tax advantages and become even more valuable as retirement accounts.
